evidence_items.text: A tug driving instructor (tug instructor) and trainee tug driver (trainee driver) were seated beside each other in the tug. The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so. The headset operator continued walking on the right side of the tug, abeam its cabin. The wingman was on the left just ahead of the tug.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.
The tug instructor pulled the aircraft forward off the fence then stopped the tug.

The airport operator and ATC were notified. Soon after, representatives from the airport operator and the RFFS were on scene. The aircraft sustained substantial damage to the rear of the aircraft, including the APU, which was running at the time.
The TRP on Taxiway Delta is between Stands 61L and 61R. There is a 14.97 m clearance behind a B737-800 and the blast fence when its nosewheel is on the TRP.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

Trainee tug driver The trainee driver was qualified as a headset operator and wingman, and was aware of the TRP through the training for these roles. This was her second pushback. The first was completed earlier that day, without event.

The trainee driver reported that she felt the tug slow down as the aircraft’s nose wheel approached the TRP, so believed the instructor would stop the pushback. However, she did not say anything when he drove past the TRP, assuming he must have known what he was doing. After the collision, she suggested not moving the aircraft off the blast fence.
Headset operator The headset operator was also qualified as a wingman. Prior to this accident, he knew about TRPs from his training for the headset operator role but had not physically seen one.

He commented that the tug instructor took over when the aircraft was abeam Stand 62 and thereafter was attending to talking to the trainee. The tug slowed down when the aircraft was abeam Stand 61, so he positioned himself to disconnect the tug from the aircraft when it stopped. However, the aircraft continued to move slowly until it hit the blast fence. He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

Wingman The wingman was also a qualified headset operator. On the day of the accident, he had been called into work at short notice. To avoid delaying the pushback, he had not collected the marshalling wands from the tug. Nevertheless, it was not mandatory to use them. He commented that the TRP was quite small.

roots_spec.exclusion_clause: Not explained by any other root
Not explained by any other root
Not explained by any other root

slot_statements.availability: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew was evident and documented during the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA incident on 12-25 in the hist_t3_prefinal phase.
slot_statements.defeater_resistance: The explanation of communication/coordination breakdown among crew in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_t3_prefinal context withstands potential defeaters, as alternative causes have been ruled out based on available evidence.
slot_statements.fit_to_key_features: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew aligns with key features observed in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_t3_prefinal case, including miscommunication and lack of coordination.

node.statement: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew was evident and documented during the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA incident on 12-25 in the hist_t3_prefinal phase.

assumptions: The statements from crew members are accurate and truthful
The absence of warnings implies a communication breakdown rather than a procedural deviation
defeaters: If evidence showed explicit, effective communication and coordination preventing the incident
If the crew had documented warnings or alerts that were acknowledged and acted upon

quotes.exact_quote: He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

The trainee driver reported that she felt the tug slow down as the aircraft’s nose wheel approached the TRP, so believed the instructor would stop the pushback. However, she did not say anything when he drove past the TRP, assuming he must have known what he was doing.
He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Direct evidence from H8, H10, and H12 shows that communication and coordination breakdown occurred: no warnings were given despite the tug passing the TRP, and crew members assumed others knew what they were doing without verbal confirmation.
outcome.uncertainty_source: No explicit transcripts or recordings of communications; reliance on post-incident statements may introduce ambiguity

node.statement: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew aligns with key features observed in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_t3_prefinal case, including miscommunication and lack of coordination.

defeaters: If evidence showed clear, effective communication and coordination preventing the incident
If crew members had actively warned or corrected each other

quotes.exact_quote: He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.
She did not say anything when he drove past the TRP, assuming he must have known what he was doing.
He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

outcome.reasoning_summary: The evidence directly shows miscommunication and lack of coordination among crew members, as the tug instructor did not receive warnings from the wingman or headset operator (H8), the trainee driver assumed the instructor knew what he was doing and did not speak up (H10), and the headset operator did not question the instructor's actions (H12).
outcome.uncertainty_source: Limited detail on the exact communication exchanges and whether other communication means were used

node.statement: The explanation of communication/coordination breakdown among crew in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_t3_prefinal context withstands potential defeaters, as alternative causes have been ruled out based on available evidence.

assumptions: Qualified personnel would have intervened if communication was effective
No other technical or procedural failures contributed
defeaters: If new evidence showed effective communication was attempted but ignored
If alternative causes such as equipment failure were identified

quotes.exact_quote: The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tugs brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

The trainee driver reported that she felt the tug slow down as the aircrafts nose wheel approached the TRP, so believed the instructor would stop the pushback. However, she did not say anything when he drove past the TRP, assuming he must have known what he was doing.
He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.
The trainee driver was qualified as a headset operator and wingman, and was aware of the TRP through the training for these roles.
The headset operator was also qualified as a wingman. Prior to this accident, he knew about TRPs from his training for the headset operator role but had not physically seen one.

The wingman was also a qualified headset operator. On the day of the accident, he had been called into work at short notice. To avoid delaying the pushback, he had not collected the marshalling wands from the tug. Nevertheless, it was not mandatory to use them.

outcome.reasoning_summary: The evidence (H8, H10, H12) shows that communication signals were limited and not effectively used, with qualified personnel aware of procedures but not intervening or warning, indicating alternative causes were considered and ruled out, supporting the claim.
outcome.uncertainty_source: lack of explicit evidence on alternative causes being fully ruled out

Witness statements explicitly describing mechanical/control failure
Maintenance records indicating prior mechanical issues

quotes.exact_quote: The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

The trainee driver reported that she felt the tug slow down as the aircraft’s nose wheel approached the TRP, so believed the instructor would stop the pushback. However, she did not say anything when he drove past the TRP, assuming he must have known what he was doing.
He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

outcome.reasoning_summary: The evidence shows the aircraft moved beyond the TRP and hit the blast barrier (H4), but no direct observation or measurement of a mechanical/control failure is reported. The continued movement appears related to human actions or decisions rather than a confirmed mechanical failure (H10, H12).
outcome.uncertainty_source: No direct evidence of mechanical/control failure; only inferred from the event outcome

slot_statements.availability: The procedural deviation in pushback execution is documented and accessible within the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 historical prefinal records.

defeaters: If documentation or records explicitly showing the procedural deviation were provided or referenced in the evidence.
outcome.reasoning_summary: No evidence in the provided history items indicates that the procedural deviation in pushback execution is documented and accessible within the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 historical prefinal records.

children_spec.statement: Crew members failed to share critical flight information in a timely manner
children_spec.test_procedure: Review cockpit voice recorder transcripts and communication logs to identify delays or omissions in information sharing

children_spec.statement: Crew did not follow established communication protocols during the flight
children_spec.test_procedure: Compare crew communication behavior against standard operating procedures and airline communication protocols

children_spec.statement: Crew coordination was impaired due to misunderstandings or misinterpretations of instructions
children_spec.test_procedure: Analyze communication exchanges for evidence of confusion or misinterpretation among crew members

children_spec.statement: External factors such as noise or equipment malfunction hindered effective communication among crew
children_spec.test_procedure: Inspect cockpit environment and equipment functionality reports to identify any communication barriers

node.statement: External factors such as noise or equipment malfunction hindered effective communication among crew

assumptions: Visual communication limitations imply possible external hindrances
Lack of warnings equates to communication breakdown influenced by external factors
defeaters: Direct evidence of noise or equipment malfunction hindering communication
Explicit reports of communication failure due to external factors

quotes.exact_quote: He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

The trainee driver reported that she felt the tug slow down as the aircraft’s nose wheel approached the TRP, so believed the instructor would stop the pushback. However, she did not say anything when he drove past the TRP, assuming he must have known what he was doing.
He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence indicates communication was primarily visual and limited, with no warnings given before the collision (H8, H10, H12). There is no direct mention of noise or equipment malfunction hindering communication, but the visual signals were insufficient and assumptions were made, suggesting external factors may have contributed indirectly.
outcome.uncertainty_source: No explicit evidence of noise or equipment malfunction; reliance on inference from limited communication and assumptions

children_spec.statement: Required environmental markings were physically present at the location
children_spec.test_procedure: Inspect the location for presence of all required environmental markings; absence or damage would lower the probability

children_spec.statement: Required environmental markings were visible and legible under operational conditions
children_spec.test_procedure: Evaluate visibility and legibility of markings under lighting and weather conditions at the time; poor visibility or illegibility would lower the probability

children_spec.statement: Required environmental markings were correctly located according to standards
children_spec.test_procedure: Compare marking locations to regulatory and operational standards; incorrect placement would lower the probability

children_spec.statement: Environmental markings were maintained and free from obstruction or damage
children_spec.test_procedure: Inspect markings for maintenance status and check for obstructions or damage; presence of obstruction or damage would lower the probability

node.statement: Environmental markings were maintained and free from obstruction or damage

defeaters: If evidence showed the TRP markings were obscured, damaged, or missing, or if the aircraft had stopped correctly at the TRP.

quotes.exact_quote: The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.
The TRP on Taxiway Delta is between Stands 61L and 61R. There is a 14.97 m clearance behind a B737-800 and the blast fence when its nosewheel is on the TRP.
He commented that the TRP was quite small.

outcome.reasoning_summary: The aircraft passed beyond the TRP ground markings and struck the blast barrier (H4), indicating the markings were present but the aircraft was not stopped at them. The TRP was described as quite small (H13), which may have contributed to the difficulty in maintaining position. The presence and location of the TRP markings are confirmed (H7). This shows the markings existed but were not effectively maintained free from obstruction or damage sufficient to prevent the incident.
outcome.uncertainty_source: No explicit statement about the physical condition or visibility of the TRP markings; ambiguity whether markings were fully clear and unobstructed.

children_spec.statement: Availability of required pushback equipment at the time of operation
children_spec.test_procedure: Check maintenance and operational logs for equipment readiness and downtime records during the pushback period

children_spec.statement: Availability of qualified personnel to perform pushback according to procedure
children_spec.test_procedure: Review staffing rosters and training records to confirm presence and qualification of pushback crew at the time

children_spec.statement: Availability of clear and accessible procedural documentation for pushback operations
children_spec.test_procedure: Verify if pushback procedure manuals or checklists were accessible and up to date during the operation

node.statement: Crew did not follow established communication protocols during the flight

assumptions: Assuming that the lack of warnings and questioning implies failure to follow communication protocols
defeaters: If evidence showed explicit communication and adherence to protocols during the pushback
If the crew had clear, documented communication procedures that were followed

quotes.exact_quote: He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.
She did not say anything when he drove past the TRP, assuming he must have known what he was doing.
He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H8, H10, and H12 indicate a lack of effective communication and warnings among crew members during the pushback, suggesting that established communication protocols were not followed.
outcome.uncertainty_source: ambiguity in whether communication protocols were formally established and what exactly they entailed

node.statement: Availability of qualified personnel to perform pushback according to procedure

assumptions: Qualification as headset operator and wingman implies sufficient training for pushback procedure
Presence of instructor and trainee in tug implies availability to perform pushback
Statements about awareness of TRP and procedures reflect actual competence
defeaters: Evidence that personnel were not qualified or trained for pushback procedure
Evidence that personnel were unavailable or incapacitated during pushback
Evidence that procedural requirements were not known or accessible to personnel

quotes.exact_quote: A tug driving instructor (tug instructor) and trainee tug driver (trainee driver) were seated beside each other in the tug.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.
The trainee driver was qualified as a headset operator and wingman, and was aware of the TRP through the training for these roles. This was her second pushback.
The headset operator was also qualified as a wingman. Prior to this accident, he knew about TRPs from his training for the headset operator role but had not physically seen one.
He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.
The wingman was also a qualified headset operator.

outcome.reasoning_summary: The evidence directly shows that qualified personnel (tug instructor, trainee driver, headset operator, wingman) were present and aware of procedures and TRP markings (H1, H9, H11, H13). The trainee was qualified and had prior experience (H9), the instructor took over and performed pushback (H2, H3), and the headset operator and wingman were qualified and aware of TRP (H11, H13). The instructor noted limitations in communication signals (H8). This supports availability of qualified personnel to perform pushback according to procedure.
outcome.uncertainty_source: No explicit procedural checklist or formal qualification records provided; reliance on statements of qualification and training awareness

node.statement: Availability of clear and accessible procedural documentation for pushback operations

defeaters: Direct evidence of formal, clear, and accessible written procedural documentation for pushback operations would change the assessment.
Evidence that all personnel had easy access to and fully understood the procedural documentation would reduce uncertainty.

quotes.exact_quote: The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view.
Trainee tug driver The trainee driver was qualified as a headset operator and wingman, and was aware of the TRP through the training for these roles.
Headset operator The headset operator was also qualified as a wingman. Prior to this accident, he knew about TRPs from his training for the headset operator role but had not physically seen one.
He commented that the TRP was quite small.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence indicates that personnel involved had training and awareness of TRP and procedures (H9, H11), but the visual signals and procedural clarity were considered insufficient or ambiguous by the tug instructor (H8), and the TRP was described as small (H13), suggesting procedural documentation may exist but is not fully clear or accessible in practice.
outcome.uncertainty_source: No explicit evidence of formal procedural documentation availability or accessibility; reliance on personnel training and statements introduces ambiguity.

node.statement: Crew members failed to share critical flight information in a timely manner

assumptions: Passing the Tug Release Point without warning constitutes failure to share critical flight information in a timely manner.
defeaters: If evidence showed timely communication or warnings were given before the incident, or if the crew had no opportunity to communicate.

quotes.exact_quote: He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.
She did not say anything when he drove past the TRP, assuming he must have known what he was doing.
He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

outcome.reasoning_summary: The evidence directly indicates that crew members (tug instructor, trainee driver, headset operator, wingman) failed to share critical flight information timely, as no warnings were given when the aircraft passed the Tug Release Point (H8, H10, H12).
outcome.uncertainty_source: No explicit timeline of communication attempts; some assumptions about what constitutes 'critical flight information'.

fit_to_key_features.statement: The mechanical/control failure aligns with the key features identified for the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA on 12-25 during hist_t3_prefinal.
